awd_titl_txt: Group Travel Award: XIIth SCAR International Biology Symposium
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will support US participation in the XIIth Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) International Biology Symposium. The theme of this meeting and ancillary workshops is Scale Matters. Meeting sessions will specifically address biodiversity and physiology spanning from molecular through ecosystem scales. 

The project will provide partial support (airfare and meeting registration) for up to 25 US participants enabling them to travel to Leuven, Belgium and attend the SCAR International Biology Symposium in July 2017. Preference will be given to applicants who are students and early career scientists. The call for applications will be broadly disseminated to encourage participation by underrepresented groups in the sciences. The SCAR International Biology Symposium is a unique opportunity for US scientists to present their work and learn about the most recent findings on all aspects of Antarctic organisms and ecosystems research, to establish and strengthen international contacts, and to be actively involved in the development of new directions and the establishment of new frontiers in polar biology.

por.por_cntn:
The United States is a member of the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR), an inter-disciplinary committee of the International Science Council. SCAR’s mission is to facilitate international scientific research in the Antarctic and the Southern Ocean. SCAR provides an important venue for international collaboration and coordination of research activities. In addition to an Open Science Conference every two years, SCAR organizes an international meeting for polar biologists every four years. 

NSF funding provided partial travel support (airfare and meeting registration) for US participants to attend the XIIth SCAR International Biology Symposium in Leuven, Belgium in July 2017. The theme of the meeting and ancillary workshops was Scale Matters. Meeting sessions specifically addressed biodiversity and physiology spanning from molecular through ecosystem scales. The SCAR International Biology Symposium is a unique opportunity for US scientists to 1) present their work, 2) learn about the most recent research projects and findings on all aspects of Antarctic organisms and ecosystems, 3) establish and strengthen international contacts and collaborations, and 4) be actively involved in the development of new directions and the establishment of new frontiers in polar biology. The call for applications was broadly disseminated to encourage participation by underrepresented groups in the sciences. Preference for travel awards was given to students and other early career scientists who would otherwise not have the means to attend an international meeting, these young scientists received 83% of the funds awarded. 

Intellectual Merit.This grant promoted the exchange of information and ideas about polar science within the US and the international Antarctic scientific community by facilitating the attendance of US scientists to attend the XIIth Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) International Biology Symposium. There were a number of ancillary meetings and workshops held in conjunction with the Symposium, providing additional opportunities for US scientists to actively engage in international discussions.

Broader Impacts.Travel support for students and other young polar scientists enhanced their career development by providing the opportunity to learn about recent advances in Antarctic research, gain experience in presenting their own research results, and establish professional relationships with other polar biologists from the US and other countries. Attending an international meeting such as the SCAR Biology Symposium can be a catalytic experience for many young investigators and a significant event in their research careers.


Last Modified: 02/07/2019
Modified by: Deneb Karentz
